Award.AwardTitle: FEW: Transformative Food Technologies to Enhance Sustainability at the Food, Energy, and Water (FEW) Nexus

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1619918
Subbiah, Jeyamkondan

Taking the food science and technology perspective, this workshop will lay groundwork for research collaborations focused on the Food-Energy-Water nexus. The workshop is scheduled for February 22-24, 2016 at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. Food, energy and water (FEW) systems are highly interconnected, and there is an urgent need to enhance understanding of how these systems are coupled. The food and bioprocessing industries offer an important opportunity to reduce water and energy use in this complex, coupled system, as solutions can target a relatively small number of establishments having a large impact. The overall goal of this workshop is to drive innovation by bringing together a diverse group of researchers, practitioners, and stakeholders from academia, industry, and government agencies to identify gaps and research needs in the area of transformative food technologies, which will enable all of these stakeholders to develop methods to improve food safety, reduce the amount of water and energy consumed, reduce the waste produced by the food processing industry, and enhance the sustainability of the FEW system.

To bring this goal to fruition, the objectives of the workshop are to: (1) Describe the state-of-the-science in food sanitation, waste reduction technologies, and transformative technologies using process design and modeling; (2) Identify the technological, socioeconomic, and behavioral barriers that must be transcended in the food and bioprocessing industry; and (3) Provide a process and venue for scientists, engineers, and stakeholders to creatively and collaboratively generate research ideas for transformative technologies to enhance sustainability in the industry and associated FEW systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The world population is projected to surpass nine billion by 2050, doubling the demand for food and feed and increasing the pressure on water and energy resources. The world’s food, energy, and water (FEW) systems are highly interconnected, and there is an urgent need to enhance understanding of how these systems are coupled. One context that presents a significant opportunity to reduce water and energy use is the food industry, as solutions for problems in this realm are capable of targeting a relatively small number of establishments and making a large impact.

To drive transformative innovation in food technologies, the University of Nebraska-Lincoln hosted a workshop in Lincoln, Nebraska, on February 22-24, 2016 to identify research needs related to transformative food technologies intended to enhance sustainability at the FEW nexus. This workshop focused on identifying FEW research needs from the food science and technology perspective. A diverse group of 56 researchers, practitioners, and stakeholders from academia, industry, and government agencies participated in this workshop. Four key themes (sanitation technologies, waste reduction technologies, process design and modeling, and socioeconomic behavior analysis to mitigate barriers for technology adoption) were initially identified. There were four keynote speakers and several breakout sessions using the jumpstart format. The ideas generated during the four sessions were compiled and grouped to identify different research topics, which were then prioritized by the participants. The following seven research needs were further discussed.   

  1. Innovative Technologies for Sanitation
  2. Waste Reduction in Processing Plants
  3. Repurposing Food Waste (Resource Recovery)
  4. Electromagnetic Technologies for Food Processing to Achieve Water and Energy Reduction
  5. Socioeconomic Behavior in Reducing Food Waste
  6. FEW Systems Modeling
  7. Detection and Sensing, Surface Interface Technologies to Improve Food Safety

Short- and long-term research needs were identified in each of the above seven research areas and described.
